Now the White House of Trump is adopting the Statue of Liberty
The safest sign of regime change is when they start attacking the statues .
The Americans appreciate this as well as any other – hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein in the Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , certainly knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe in a heated dispute with Jim Acosta of CNN about the president ’ s proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration with the Statue of Liberty .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A Horde of boat owners and liberty imitators would have liked him to have done so .
But he attacked its importance , and especially the importance attributed to it when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument , its base .
When Miller accused Acosta : " I don 't want to go into a complete thing about history here , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that enlightens the world .
The poem to which you refer , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Freedom . '
Miller is factually right , but as he himself put it , it is not really about history .

It is about contemporary resonance to Lazarus 's raging words , the only one in which a state invites not only any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your tired , your poor , your afflicted masses , who yearn to breathe freely / the miserable waste of your rich coasts ' .
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' was better visible on our screens .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict because of the importance of a statue is part of a broader political and cultural debate : it is indeed a conflict about America ’ s importance .
Lazarus - and her friends , who were committed to putting their words on the ground after their death - knew very well that they did a highly political act .
The sculpture was supposed to show the links between French and American Republicanism by representing the female embodiment of freedom in a weighted classical representation .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of exiles .
The connection of the poem with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people from the right wing wanted to change this for a long time .

The great shepherd Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Freedom is not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative that brings the American flame into the overnight world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It should carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch should not illuminate the path to the United States . '
Quite unusual , Limbaugh has found something here .
The importance of the statue is quite a matter of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see it as seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
The truth is to see the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome they must hear .
And that , of course , is not the perspective that Miller and Trump ever want to recognize .
Their torch is not intended to illuminate the path , but to ignite the hatred , which is its only source of power .

Poverty and Death in the Indonesian Goldland
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai Regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour the cooled bone is removed and swallowed with diligent , unwashed hands .
Degei is sitting on the mud floor - she has no furniture - where she also performs her daily work , such as washing clothes with mud water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband 's four wives , she was not assigned fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , late work can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
No one dares to walk around in the village after 5 p.m. ,  she says . . .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony that was admitted in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were to vote by public hand-raising before the occupying forces .

An existing movement that stirred up for independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the government of Jakarta , which maintains control of the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers from it .
In 2003 the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent part of Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
Enarotali is as remote as it is deserted .
There is no public transport .
The town with about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated roofs converted by rust into different yellow brown tones .
Few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and virtually no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not accustomed to wearing this clothing ,  says Degei , pointing to her lively hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and her bright rock .
'In the past we had only leaves on our bodies ' .
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and some of the worst child mortality and literacy rates in Asia .
But it is also Indonesia ’ s goldland .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by the Freeport McMoran from Phoenix , is located only 60 miles from Paniai , a highlands province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport , worth $ 3.1 billion , reduced gold and copper .
Moreover , Papua has an estimated $ 78 billion worth of wood resources .
But these wealth is a source of misery for the Papua , which ensures that Indonesia ’ s powerful military preserves a stifling presence .
A 2005 study in the New York Times reported that Freeport paid local military and units nearly $ 20 million between 1998 and 2004 , including up to $ 150,000 to a single officer .
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten these golden ganes and are treated mercilessly .
According to activists , more than 500,000 Papua have been killed and thousands have been raped , tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969 .
Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal highlands in the 1970 ’ s became genocide under the Asian Human Rights Commission .
In the region alone , the Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year .

We will lose everything  is stated in a 2016 Archdiocese report by Brisbane , which contains reports of atrocities of the previous year , such as illegal executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal defeat of peaceful demonstrations .

The screws have increased , as Papua ’ s resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .
